blocks.text:
To integrate the left-hand side, let u = c 2 + x 2 
then  
du = 2x dx  
Thus, by integration of equation (1),  
  
  
Now at the point A (Fig. 1.36) we have: y = 0.

Squaring  
s 2 = c 2 + x 2 
But as proved above  
c 2 = s 2 - y 2 - z c 

Separating the variables  
du = dy.

blocks.latex: \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{(\log \left( e^{c} \right) + C_{0})}{{y}}}} = \int ds = log \left( \frac{y}{(\log \left( e^{c} \right) + C_{0})} \right) + C_{1}.
blocks.description: This equation represents the integration involving logarithmic relationships.

blocks.text:
Integrating and this integral is of the type discussed on p. 151; the result being  
log \left( \frac{y}{\log \left( e^{c} \right) + C_{0}} \right) + C_{1}.

Thus  

y = 0 when  y = 0, being measured from the vertical axis through A, and thus  
\log \left( \frac{e^{c}}{C_{0}} \right) + C_{0} = 0.

Isolating the surd  
s 2 - c 2 = (y + z) + c 2.

blocks.description: This equation shows the relationship between c, y, and z.
